titleStmt.title: Letter from Amy Lowell to Eunice Tietjens, July 18, 1919
titleStmt.author: Amy Lowell
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Textual Studies and Digital Humanities, Loyola University Chicago

physDesc.p: Single page with main letter written in typewritten text. Lowell's signature and postscript are written in her handwriting. The final lines of the postscript are written vertically in the lower left margin.

body.p: I am horrified to discover that in that list of poetry books that I made out for Doubleday, Page & Company, Profiles from China," which I especially included, has been omitted. The reason for this is that the book is out of print—at least so Mr. Seymour reports—and Alfred Knopf says that he is to issue a new edition, but it is not yet ready. I have wrestled hard with Mr. Crowell, who is the head of the Lord and Taylor Book Shop, and he has just written regretting very much that “Profiles from China” was left out of the first publicity list, but says that it shall be included in subsequent ones. Feeling as I do about that book, the idea of having any list come out without it is horrible to me, and in case you might see the list, I wish it clearly understood what was the reason of the omission.
I hope that all is going well with you. I think that I may go through Chicago on my way back from Grand Rapids where I am lecturing this Autumn, in which case I hope that I may see you.

postscript.add: P.S. In reading over this letter, it seems to me that I have put it as though Mr. Crowell left the book out of his list for any reason but the true one. You understand, he is as eager as I to list it, but as we were only printing procurable books, he felt it could not go on, until we got a date of republication from Mr. Knopf. He is an energetic and enthusiastic publisher, Knopf. I told him my high regard for “Profiles”
when I saw him at the Bookseller’s dinner. I am awfully glad he is to bring it out.

div.note: Efforts to trace Mr. Seymour’s identity have not been successful.
